Dialogue:
[doctor] all right . today i am seeing jose james . uh , date of birth 9/29/1957 . mr . james is a new patient who's having pain in his left shoulder and elbow . he fell five months ago going up a stairs , and the pain has been present since .
[doctor] hi mr . james , i'm doctor isabella . how are you doing ?
[patient] i'm okay . thank you .
[doctor] that's good . that's good . tell me what's brings you in today .
[patient] sure . so i've been having constant pain in my left shoulder and left elbow for a while , about five months or so . hurts all the time . pretty bad at times .
[doctor] mm . that does not sound like fun . it sounds like you injured it going up the stairs ?
[patient] yes , that's correct . it was icy , and i have to walk up a flight of stairs to my house . i stepped and my feet just went out . fell on my left side . seems like my shoulder and wrist took the brunt . it's been hurting since .
[doctor] yeah , that does seem like a likely cause of your symptoms . anything seem to make the pain worse ?
[patient] well , i've always hit the gym and lifted weights . i've been trying to keep with my routine of two days a week , but it's been hard . the pain is worse when i lift , and i have n't been able to lift more than 15 or 20 pounds which is very frustrating .
[doctor] mm-hmm . i can imagine it is when you're so accustomed to your routine .
[patient] exactly . i really enjoy my exercise , but over the past one to two weeks , i've stopped hitting the gym because the pain just was n't worth it honestly . i do keep up with my walking , though . my wife and i walk about 30 minutes almost every day . we have done this since i retired from my office job last year .
[doctor] i do not blame you , mr . james . does anything seem to help the pain that you've tried ?
[patient] not too much . i have iced a bit , but i have not taken anything for the pain . stopping exercise and some ice has helped a bit , but it still hurts enough for me to come to see you .
[doctor] yeah , okay . how about any numbness or tingling ? have you felt that at any point ?
[patient] no , doc . just pain . no tingling or numbless , numbness , thankfully .
[doctor] understood . understood . all right . well , let's go ahead and take a look and see what's going on .
[patient] sounds good . thank you .
[doctor] okay . use my general physical exam template . mr . james , i'm going to gently press around your shoulder and elbow here to see where your pain might be stemming from . just let me know when it hurts .
[patient] okay . it hurts when you press there on my elbow and here on my shoulder .
[doctor] okay . left shoulder and elbow , tender sa space , no warmth , erythema or deformity . positive hawkins-kennedy and neer's test . normal proximal and distar , distal upper extremity strength . intact median radial ulnar sensation and abduction to 90 degrees . normal empty tan , can test . okay , mr . james , w-what i think you are dealing with is impingement syndrome of your left shoulder . i do n't think there's an additional injury or issue with your wrist , but because everything is connected , you're experiencing pain in your wrist because of your shoulder . we do see this type of issue when someone has a fall , so it's good you came to see us , you came in to see us so we could help .
[patient] so what are the possible treatments ?
[doctor] well , we have a few options you can try . first option would be to start with physical therapy . i would recommend two sessions per week as well as any other exercises they give you to do at home . we can start there and if that does n't improve your pain , then we could try a cortisone injection .
[patient] i like the idea of starting with the physical therapy and have a next step if it does n't help . i am not opposed to a shot but would like to try the therapy first .
[doctor] all right . great . i'll get a referral order , and they will call you within the next day or two to get you scheduled .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] mm-hmm . also , please continue to ice , especially your shoulder , and rest as much as you can .
[patient] okay . i will .
[doctor] give us a call or email us if you have symptoms worsen , if your symptoms worsen or do not improve with the therapy .
[patient] will do . thank you . i appreciate your help .
[doctor] you're welcome . have a great day .
[patient] you too .
[doctor] all right . assessment is impingement syndrome of left shoulder . plan discussed with patient . referral is requested for dr. martha rivera to be in physical therapy two days per week .
label: sub
note_1:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Left shoulder and elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Mr. Jose James is a 67 year-old male who presented with left shoulder and elbow pain. Patient had a fall at home when walking up a flight of stairs about 5 months ago. He landed on left side and his shoulder and wrist took the brunt. The patient had constant pain in the left shoulder and left elbow since then. This pain was exacerbated by lifting weights. Stopping exercise and ice therapy only slightly improve the pain. Denies any numbness or tingling. The pain was significant enough to prevent him from going to gym in the past 2 weeks. He then presented to clinic for further evaluation
note_2:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Left shoulder and elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant [age]-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of left shoulder and elbow pain. The patient reports falling down a flight of stairs approximately 5 months ago, resulting in left shoulder and elbow pain. He describes the pain as constant and severe, making it difficult for him to perform daily activities such as lifting weights. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm.
note_3:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Left shoulder and elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Mr. James is a new patient who presents with a 5-month history of constant pain in his left shoulder and elbow. The pain began after he fell down a flight of stairs and landed on his left side. He has been trying to continue his weightlifting routine, but the pain has been worse when he lifts. He has stopped going to the gym in the past 1-2 weeks because the pain is too severe. He does continue to walk for 30 minutes almost every day with his wife. He has tried icing the area, but it has not provided much relief. He denies any numbness or tingling.

label: ap
note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Impingement syndrome of left shoulder
Assessment: Patient had significant left shoulder and elbow pain after a fall 5 months ago. He has no tingling or numbness. Physical exam showed tenderness on elbow and shoulder, positive Hawkins-Kennedy and neerâ€™s test. Sensation was intact. Patient's presentation is likely due to impingement syndrome
Plan:
-Refer to physical therapy 2 days a week
-Will consider a cortisone injection if physical therapy failed to  improve pain
-Continue to apply ice therapy and rest
-Call back to clinic if symptoms worsen
note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Impingement syndrome of left shoulder
Assessment: The patient presents with left shoulder and elbow pain, tenderness to palpation, positive Hawkin's Kennedy and Neer's tests, and limited range of motion. No warmth, erythema, or deformity. Normal proximal and distal upper extremity strength. Intact median radial ulnar sensation and abduction to 90 degrees. Normal empty tan, can test.
Plan:
- Referral to physical therapy twice per week.
- Continue icing and rest as needed.
- If symptoms worsen or do not improve with physical therapy, will consider corticosteroid injection.

Follow-up instructions:
- Call or email the office if symptoms worsen or do not improve with physical therapy.
note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Impingement Syndrome of Left Shoulder
Assessment: Tenderness to palpation over the left shoulder and elbow. Positive Hawkins-Kennedy and Neer's tests. Normal proximal and distal upper extremity strength. Intact median, radial, and ulnar sensation. Abduction to 90 degrees. Normal empty can test. History of fall five months ago, which is a common cause of impingement syndrome
Plan:
- Physical therapy twice per week
- Continue icing and rest
- Follow up if symptoms worsen or do not improve with therapy

label: sub
note_1:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Headaches

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
This is a _ year old woman who presented today for evaluation of headaches. She has a history of headaches since her teenage years, usually occurring around her menses. Over the years, she has noticed that headaches can occur when she is under stress. She has observed that her headaches have become more frequent and severe recently. The headache is primarily located behind the right eye, and is pulsating in nature. Physical activities, such as jogging, trigger the headache. The headache is accompanied by ear ringing and blurry vision. She denies experiencing tingling or numbness.
note_2:
CHIEF COMPLAINT 
Headache, blurred vision, ringing in the ears. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS 
The patient is a pleasant female who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of headache, blurred vision, and ringing in the ears. She reports a history of headaches dating back to adolescence, initially associated with menstrual cycles, later associated with stress, and currently occurring more frequently and severely. The headaches are described as right-sided, pulsing, and associated with visual disturbances. She also reports a ringing in her ears for several months and blurred vision intermittently. She denies any numbness or tingling to her hands, feet, or face. She notes that her headaches worsen with exercise, and she uses New Balance and Asics shoes for running.
note_3:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Headaches.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant female who presents with a CHIEF COMPLAINT of headaches. She has been experiencing headaches for years, but they have recently become more frequent and severe. The headaches are typically located on the right side of her head, behind her eye, and are described as a pulsing sensation. They are exacerbated by exercise and are associated with tinnitus and blurred vision. She denies any numbness or tingling in her hands or feet. She has been using New Balance and Asics running shoes. She has not had a recent MRI of her brain.

label: ap
note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Headache, possible idiopathic intracranial hypertension
Assessment: The patient presented with recurrent headaches that worsen with activity, associated with tinnitus and vision changes. Fundoscopy reveals papilledema. Further testing is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other potential causes.
Plan:
- Obtain a brain MRI, pending insurance preapproval, followed by a lumbar puncture with open pressure measurement, including a possible therapeutic CSF tap.
- Refer to a neuro-ophthalmologist for a complete eye examination.
- If idiopathic intracranial hypertension is confirmed, we will attempt medical management, supplemented with exercise and weight loss.
note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Headache, suspected idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) 
Assessment: The patient presented with recurrent headaches, worsened with exercise, associated with visual disturbances, ear ringing, and blurred vision. These symptoms are consistent with IIH. Differential diagnoses include migraine, tension headache, and occipital neuralgia. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain MRI brain to confirm diagnosis. 
- Will perform lumbar puncture to assess CSF pressure. 
- Refer to neuro-ophthalmology for comprehensive eye exam. 
- Consider medications to reduce pressure in the brain, such as acetazolamide or topiramate. 

2. Exercise-induced headaches 
Assessment: The patient experiences headaches after exercising, suggesting that exercise may trigger or exacerbate their headaches. 
Plan: 
- Encourage regular exercise and weight loss. 

3. Blurred vision 
Assessment: The patient reported blurred vision, which may be related to IIH. 
Plan: 
- Obtain ophthalmologic evaluation. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 week for results of MRI brain and lumbar puncture.
note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension (IIH)
Assessment: Symptoms of headaches, worsening with activity, ringing in the ears, and blurred vision. Funduscopic exam reveals papilledema. Neurological exam shows intact cranial nerves and normal gait.
Plan:
- Diagnostic:
    - MRI to rule out other underlying conditions.
    - Spinal tap to evaluate intracranial pressure.
    - Neuro-ophthalmologist referral for a complete eye exam.
- Therapeutic:
    - Medications to decrease intracranial pressure (to be determined after test results).
    - Exercise and weight loss as part of treatment.

Follow-up Instructions:
- Patient will be contacted to schedule MRI once insurance preapproval is obtained.
- Patient will be referred to a neuro-ophthalmologist for a complete eye exam.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
This is a _ year-old woman with a past medical history of hypertension, diabetes, nephrolithiasis, who presented for evaluation of kidney stone which passed about 3 days ago. The patient was in the emergency room last week due to pain related to the kidney stone; Percocet was prescribed for pain control. She reported that the stone had passed 3 days ago. She denied seeing any hematuria currently. The pain has resolved. The patient last saw a urologist about 1 year ago.

The patient reported that her blood pressure has improved and is usually 130 to 140 over 60 to 70 mmHg at home. She is taking Norvasc 2.5mg. She admitted to having been consuming some fast food. She takes metformin for diabetes. She does not check  her blood sugar very often.

The patient continues to have some insomnia but is improving after trying some meditation app. She is not interested in any sleeping pills.

She denied any chest pain or abdominal pain.

CHIEF COMPLAINT
Kidney stone pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant female who presents with a history of recurrent kidney stones. She reports that she has had approximately seven or eight kidney stones in the past. She states that the pain from her most recent kidney stone has been intermittent, and she went to the emergency room last week for pain. She believes that the stone has now passed, as she has not had any pain or blood in her urine for the past three days. She has not seen a urologist in about a year.

The patient also has a past medical history of hypertension and diabetes. She is currently taking 2.5 mg of Norvasc for her hypertension and 500 mg of metformin daily for her diabetes. She reports that she has been taking her medications regularly, but her blood pressure has been a little high at home. She has been advised to get a blood pressure cuff and take her blood pressure at home two to three times per week. Her readings at home have been in the range of 130-140/60-70 mmHg. She admits to having difficulty controlling her diet, as she eats fast food and sugary foods on a regular basis. She is unsure if she can make another appointment with a dietitian.

The patient's blood sugars have been running in the range of 130-140 mg/dL. Her last A1c was 6.7%. She does not check her blood sugars very often. The patient denies any chest pain or abdominal pain.

note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Recurrent nephrolithiasis
Assessment: It appears that the patient passed another kidney stone about 3 days ago. She has had multiple past occurrences of kidney stones. She is currently pain free. No abdominal tenderness on exam.
Plan:
- Refer to urology, Dr. Harris as per the patient's request
- Obtain urinalysis and urine culture

2. Hypertension
Assessment: Blood pressure today is 150/90 mmHg; however, she reports that her BP has been better at home, usually 130 to 140 over 60 to 70 mmHg. White coat syndrome is possible.
Plan:
- Continue Norvasc 2.5 mg
- Recommend a low sodium diet of 2300 mg or less of sodium per day, avoid fast food or prepackaged food. Consult a nutritionist.

3. Type 2 diabetes
Assessment: Hemoglobin A1c 6.7%, improving compared to when first diagnosed.
Plan:
- Continue metformin 500mg
- Recommend starting to check blood glucose before every meal

4. Insomnia
Assessment: The patient still has occasional insomnia. She felt the meditation app was helpful.
Plan:
- Discussed proper sleep hygiene.
- Melatonin 10mg as needed.

Follow-up instructions:
Return to the clinic in 3 months.

note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Recurrent Kidney Stones
Assessment: Patient has a history of recurrent kidney stones and has experienced multiple episodes in the past. Patient reports passing a stone three days ago and is currently pain-free. No blood in urine or ongoing pain.
Plan:
- Obtain urinalysis and urine culture to confirm stone passage and rule out infection.
- Refer to urology for further evaluation and management of recurrent stone formation.

2. Hypertension
Assessment: Patient's blood pressure is slightly elevated at 150/90 mmHg. Patient is currently taking 2.5 mg of norvasc, which has been effective in controlling blood pressure.Patient reports good blood pressure control at home, suggesting possible white coat syndrome.
Plan:
- Continue norvasc 2.5 mg daily.
- Recommend home blood pressure monitoring 2-3 times per week to assess blood pressure control outside of the clinic setting.
- Refer to nutrition for dietary counseling to assist with sodium restriction and weight management.

3. Diabetes
Assessment: Patient has a history of type 2 diabetes and is taking 500 mg of metformin daily. Patient reports infrequent blood sugar monitoring and estimates that blood sugars have been "pretty good." Last A1c was 6.7%, indicating moderate hyperglycemia.
Plan:
- Continue metformin 500 mg daily.
- Instruct patient to monitor blood sugars before every meal to assess glycemic control and adjust food intake accordingly.

4. Insomnia
Assessment: Patient reports occasional insomnia due to worry and difficulty falling asleep.Patient has tried meditation apps and sleep hygiene measures with limited success. Patient is hesitant to take sleeping pills.
Plan:
- Prescribe melatonin 10 mg as needed for sleep.
- Reinforce sleep hygiene measures, including avoiding electronics before bed, creating a dark and cool sleep environment, and practicing relaxation techniques.

Follow-up Instructions:
- Return to clinic in three months for follow-up of hypertension, diabetes, and insomnia.
- Contact the office if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

This patient presented for evaluation of chronic back pain for a couple of years. The pain initially started after he was moving furniture. He described the pain as sharp and stabbing, traveling down to his right leg sometimes all the way to his big toe. It feels worse when he sits down. It's associated with numbness and tingling to the right leg sometimes. He denied loss of sensation in the genital or the rectal area, no weakness, no bowel or bladder incontinence. He had tried physical therapy and pain medications that provided temporary relief. He would like to avoid surgery. It has been affecting his daily activity and has been gaining weight due to this.
note_2:
CHIEF COMPLAINT 
Chronic lumbar back pain. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS 
The patient is a pleasant [age]-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of chronic lumbar back pain. The patient reports he has been experiencing back pain for approximately two years, which began after moving furniture one weekend. He describes the pain as a sharp stabbing pain in his back, which can extend down to his right leg, including his big toe. He also experiences numbness and tingling in his right leg, particularly down to his foot. He denies any loss of sensation in the genital or rectal areas. He also denies any weakness, loss of control of his bladder or bowels, or difficulty ambulating. The patient states he has tried physical therapy and strong pain medications in the past, but these interventions provided only temporary relief. He also mentions that surgery was discussed in the past, but he would prefer to avoid surgery. The patient notes that his day is limited due to his back pain, and he has gained weight over the past few years. He previously played golf, but this activity has been challenging due to his back pain. He denies any family history of spine conditions, smokes, or alcohol use.

Chronic lumbar back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant male who presents with a 2-year history of chronic lumbar back pain. The pain began after he moved furniture one weekend. He describes the pain as a sharp, stabbing pain that radiates down his right leg to his big toe. He also experiences numbness and tingling in his right leg and foot. He denies any weakness, loss of sensation in the genital or rectal area, or loss of control of his bladder or bowels. He has tried physical therapy and strong pain medications in the past, but they have only provided temporary relief. He has also been advised to consider surgery, but he would like to avoid it if possible. He is overweight and has gained weight over the past few years due to his back pain. He used to play golf, but his back pain has set him back. He has no family history of spine conditions. He quit smoking 20 years ago.

label: ap
note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Chronic lumbar back pain due to L4-5 disk herniation with radiculopathy
Assessment: Patient presented with lumbar back pain with radiation to right leg/toe. Exams show midline tenderness at L4-5 disk space with right lumbar paravertebral tenderness, pain with lumbar flexion. Straight leg test is positive. Decreased sensation to light touch right lateral thigh L4 dermatome. MRI shows disk herniation with nerve impingement.
Plan:
- Recommend glucocorticoid spinal injection under fluoroscopy
note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Chronic lumbar back pain 
Assessment: The patient presents with chronic lumbar back pain, likely due to L4-L5 herniated disc with radiculopathy. He has tried various treatments including physical therapy, pain medications, and surgery, but none have provided relief. His exam reveals midline tenderness at L4-L5 disk space with right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness. Decreased sensation to light touch at the right lateral thigh at L4 dermatome. Patellar and Achilles reflexes are symmetrical. MRI shows disk herniation with nerve impingement. 
Plan: 
- Will perform spinal injection with a strong inflammatory medication called a corticosteroid. 
- Monitor response to treatment and repeat injection every 3 months if needed.
note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Chronic Lumbar Back Pain
Assessment: Symptoms consistent with L4-L5 herniated disk with radiculopathy, based on patient's history, physical exam, and MRI results. Disk herniation is impinging on nerves, causing tingling in the right leg.
Plan:
- Spinal injection with corticosteroid to reduce inflammation and relieve pain.
- Monitor response to injection and consider additional injections as needed (up to 4 per year).

Follow-up Instructions:
- Patient will be discharged after the injection.
- Follow-up appointment will be scheduled to monitor response and determine need for further injections.

1. Allergic Asthma 
Assessment: The patient has recently developed shortness of breath, eye watering, and diarrhea after exposure to his cat and outdoor environment. He denies any history of allergies or respiratory problems in the past. Physical exam reveals faint expiratory wheezing bilaterally in all lung fields. Chest X-ray and pulmonary function tests were normal. Differential diagnosis includes allergic rhinitis, sinusitis, or viral upper respiratory tract infection. However, given the sudden onset of symptoms and improvement with nebulizer treatment, allergic asthma is the most likely diagnosis. 
Plan: 
- Continue albuterol inhaler as needed for symptom relief. 
- Prescribe Singulair 10 mg Qday. 
- Schedule allergy testing.

Assessment: The patient reports that his cat causes him to experience shortness of breath and eye watering. 
Plan: 
- Recommend keeping the cat away from the patient. 

3. Diarrhea 
Assessment: The patient experiences diarrhea after heavy drinking. 
Plan: 
- Advise the patient to limit alcohol intake. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 week for skin testing.
note_3:

Plan:
- Continue albuterol inhaler as needed for symptoms.
- Prescribe Singulair 10mg daily to reduce asthma occurrences.
- Schedule allergy skin testing next week to identify potential triggers.

- Bring cat to the appointment for possible exposure during testing.

label: ap
note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Diabetic R foot ulcer
Assessment: Patient presents with worsening redness of right foot ulcer with associated drainage. vital signs unremarkable. 1 by 2 inches circular wound appreciated on the dorsal aspect of the lateral foot just proximal to the fifth MTP joint. Some redness and drainage seen with some surrounding edema.  No necrosis, no bony exposure and no odor appreciated.  Patient denies any tenderness to palpation. last a1c greater than 10. Xray unremarkable for osteomyelitis of right foot. Patient likely has an infected right foot ulcer precipitated by uncontrolled diabetes
Plan:
-ABI ankle-brachial index 
-debridement to remove dead tissue
-Clindamycin 400 mg b.i.d.for 7 days 
-Surgical shoe for the next month 
-follow up with PCP for diabetes
-Return 2 weeks to clinic with possibly on the debridement at that time
-If patient Develops a fever or not feeling well, he was informed to  present to urgent care
note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Diabetic foot ulcer 
Assessment: The patient has a nonhealing, red, and draining foot ulcer. He has a history of diabetes and poorly controlled A1C (around 10). X-ray shows no evidence of osteomyelitis. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain ABIs to evaluate blood flow to the foot. 
- Will perform debridement of the ulcer. 
- Will prescribe Clindamycin 400mg Q8h for 7 days. 
- Will provide the patient with a surgical shoe to wear during the treatment period. 
- Will follow up with the patient in 2 weeks to reassess the ulcer and consider additional debridement. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- If any problems arise between visits, please call the office. 
- If experiencing fevers, chills, or black discharge, seek immediate medical attention at the urgent care or ER.
note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Diabetic foot ulcer
Assessment: Non-healing foot ulcer for two months. Redness, drainage, and throbbing pain. No fever or bony exposure. X-ray shows no osteomyelitis. Patient has poorly controlled diabetes (A1c around 10)
Plan:
- Order ankle-brachial index (ABI) to assess blood supply
- Debridement of dead tissue
- Prescribe clindamycin 400mg twice daily for 7 days
- Provide surgical shoe for offloading pressure
- Follow-up in two weeks for reassessment and possible further debridement

Follow-up instructions:
- Call the office if any concerns or worsening symptoms
- Seek urgent care or emergency medical attention if fever, chills, or severe pain develops

3. Kidney Transplant

Plan:
-Continue follow-up with Dr. Reyes for immunosuppression management.
-Dr. Reyes will contact the doctor if needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT
Upper respiratory infection.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Andrew is a 59 yo M with a past medical history of depression, type 2 diabetes, and hypertension who presented today for an upper respiratory infection. The patient had exertional dyspnea and fatigue in the last week.  He felt like he had caught his 1st cold this year. The shortness of breath was exacerbated by lifting or carrying something. This was a dry cough and  fever. He also had elbow pain and tension in the knees.  Denies any nausea/vomiting/diarrhea.  He had received 2 dosages of COVID-19 vaccines.  Denies any history of seasonal allergies.
Regarding depression, the patient had been doing fine without medication.  He was active with exercise and participated in Barre classes
He had been monitoring blood sugar and blood pressure regularly on workdays, but not over the weekends. He reported blood pressure and blood sugar had been under control.

His depression has been stable, and he has been attending barre classes to help him relax.

His blood pressure has been controlled with lisinopril, but he has not been consistent with monitoring his blood pressure at home.

note_1:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Annual checkup.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Andrea is a 52-year-old female with a past medical history of rheumatoid arthritis, atrial fibrillation, and GERD who presented for annual exam. The patient reported being stable with her arthritis in the past 1 year. She had been doing exercise, such as yoga and walking. She did not have any joint pain, stiffness of flare-ups.  She had been compliant with methotrexate once weekly dosing.   However, she continued to have palpitations, with last episode about 1 week ago.  This was triggered by stress.  Meditation and relaxation had not been helping. She had a event monitor one month ago which showed paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Patient was also taking Protonix  and doing dietary modifications for acid reflux.  She denies any flare of GERD in the past 5 months. note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Positive Hepatitis C antibody
Assessment:
Patient presents to clinic after being found to have a positive hepatitis C antibody.  Physical examination unremarkable. She has no jaundice.  Abdominal exam unremarkable and no signs of hepatosplenomegaly. She tested positive for HCV antibody and was found to have an elevated AST of 39 on liver function testing. Remainder of liver function tests unremarkable.   She does carry risk factors for hepatitis C infection as she has a history of IV drug use.
Plan: 
-Will order hepatitis C RNA  and genotype
-Ultrasound to evaluate for fibrosis of the liver and severity of liver disease 
-Informed patient to set up appointment for patient's wife and kids with family doctor for  Hepatitis C screening.
-Return to clinic in about 3 weeks
note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Hepatitis C 
Assessment: The patient's HCV Ab test was positive, and her liver panel showed an elevated AST (39), but her ALB, Tbili, and INR were within normal limits. This suggests that she has chronic hepatitis C. 
Plan: 
- Confirm the diagnosis with HCV RNA and HCV genotype. 
- Determine the severity of liver disease by checking for fibrosis of the liver with a special ultrasound. 
- Start treatment after determining the severity of the disease. 

2. Fatigue 
Assessment: The patient reports feeling tired at the end of the day despite cutting back on smoking and alcohol use. She denies any changes in appetite, weight loss, fevers, chills, night sweats, or hematuria. Her physical exam is unremarkable. 
Plan: 
- Continue to monitor fatigue and consider further evaluation if it persists or worsens.
note_3:

1. Hepatitis C
Assessment: Positive HCV antibody test. Elevated AST (39 U/L). No jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, or ascites on physical exam. History of IV drug use and heavy alcohol use in the past. No current symptoms of liver disease
Plan:
- Diagnostic:
    - HCV RNA and genotype testing
    - Liver ultrasound to assess fibrosis
- Therapeutic:
    - Will discuss treatment options once the severity of liver disease is determined

2. Hypertension

Plan:

3. Fatigue
Assessment: Patient reports feeling tired at the end of the day despite adequate sleep. No other symptoms or signs of underlying medical conditions
Plan:
- Encourage patient to continue working on reducing work hours
- Consider referral to a mental health professional to rule out depression

Follow-up Instructions:
- Return to clinic in three weeks for follow-up of hepatitis C evaluation
- Have wife and children tested for hepatitis C

[doctor] judy gomez , mrn 869723 . date of birth , 5 , 7 , 1961 . she's in office today for ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis . hello , judy , how are you doing today ?
[patient] i'm doing good , thank you . how are you ?
[doctor] i'm great , thanks . so how have you been since the last time ? i know the last time we were talking about decreasing your prednisone dose , correct ?
[patient] yes . i'm just on one now and that seems to be enough .
[doctor] aw , that's great to hear .
[patient] yeah , there were a couple days there i took an extra one , just because there was a little extra pain in my feet . and i do have a desk job , so when i have a day off where i'm moving around a lot they do tend to hurt a bit more .
[doctor] okay . how many times did you do that ?
[patient] um , it was n't often , maybe once a week .
[doctor] okay . so it sounds like we're still on track for discontinuing the prednisone . we'll do that today and you can let me know how it goes on your next visit . and how about the methotrexate , do you think that helped with your joint pain ?
[patient] yeah , definitely . because i went to get my covid shots , um , but from the letter i got about it , it said that it could interfere with the vaccine , you know , reduce the efficacy . so i did n't take it on the week that i got the first shot .
[doctor] okay . and what happened ?
[patient] i felt absolutely horrible until i took it again a week later .
[doctor] i'm sorry to hear that . and- and what did you do about the second dose ?
[patient] well , i called into the hotline because i was in so much pain with the first one . and they said , " no , just go ahead and take it , " so i did .
[doctor] okay . that's good then . we do have to keep an eye out on it since it's a high-risk medication . do you have an appointment to get your blood drawn for the next time ?
[patient] no , they did n't give me one .
[doctor] okay . so we can do that for you too . uhm , so what questions do you have for me , judy ?
[patient] well , i just wanted to know why i was getting all these bruises here , so like when i bump myself . i do n't know where they're coming from .
[doctor] okay . that's probably from the prednisone , it can increase bruising .
[patient] okay . i did n't know that . um , i do n't even feel it when it happens , they just show up .
[doctor] yeah . unfortunately that can happen , but we're working on discontinuing that so let's see if the bruises do go away .
[patient] okay . that sounds good , thanks .
[doctor] okay , judy , please , um , sit up here and i'll take a look . shoes and socks off please .
[patient] all right .
[doctor] all right . let me see here . okay . so where is it hurting ? in your joints right here ?
[patient] yeah , a little . also in my feet joints as well .
[doctor] okay . and how about when you bend the knee like this ?
[patient] well , it hurt before we increased the methotrexate , but it's doing pretty good now .
[doctor] okay , good . can you flex your toes please ? good range of motion . also ridges in nails , that's from the psoriasis .
[patient] yeah . they've been like that for a long time now .
[doctor] okay . all right , uhm , ms gomez , it looks like we're moving along with your treatment nicely . we'll stop your prednisone and continue with the methotrexate . make sure to stop by the front desk and make an appointment for the blood work , and i'll see you in three months .
[patient] all right . it sounds good . thank you so much , it was great to see you .
[doctor] it was great seeing you too . thank you .
label: sub
note_1:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Ms. Judy Gomez is a 62-year-old female who presents to the office today for ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis.

History of presenting illness
Patient states that she is feeling great. On her last visit, plan was to decrease her prednisone dose. She is currently on 1 mg of prednisone but takes an extra dose once a week on her day off from her desk job for worsening pain as a result of walking more.  She is also on methotrexate and states it has helped with her joint pain. She mentions holding her dose for the covid shot where she felt horrible until she restarted the medication a week later. She recently received her second COVID shot.  She mentions increased bruising when she bumps herself.
note_2:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
On going management of psoriatic arthritis.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant female who presents for ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis. She reports feeling good overall, except for some pain in her feet which has improved since reducing her prednisone dosage. She had taken an extra dose of prednisone occasionally due to increased pain, but has not done so recently. The patient reports that the methotrexate has helped with her joint pain. She received two doses of the COVID-19 vaccine, but experienced severe pain after the first dose and therefore did not receive the second dose until a week later. She has noticed bruising on her body, particularly on her arms and legs, which may be related to the prednisone.
note_3:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Judy Gomez, a pleasant 60-year-old female, presents for ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis. She reports that her pain has improved since increasing her methotrexate dose. She has been taking one prednisone daily, but has occasionally taken an extra dose due to increased pain in her feet. She has noticed increased bruising, which she attributes to the prednisone. She has not had any recent changes in her joint pain or other symptoms.

label: ap
note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Psoriatic arthritis
Assessment: she mentions intermittent pain in her feet with increased ambulation, once a week, which she treats with an extra dose of prednisone. She also mentions easy bruising. Pain in joints of feet on examination. No pain on bending the knee.  Good range of motion of toes. Ridges on nails secondary to psoriasis Patient is progressing well with treatment. She does have some bruising which is likely secondary to prednisone.
Plan: 
-Discontinue prednisone 
-Continue methotrexate
-Order blood work 
-Follow up in 3 months.
note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Psoriatic Arthritis
Assessment: The patient has been taking one dose of prednisone per week, which is not sufficient to control her symptoms. She also had some adverse effects from the methotrexate, such as feeling horrible after taking it. However, she reports improvement in her symptoms after restarting the methotrexate.
Plan:
- Discontinue prednisone.
- Continue methotrexate at current dosage.
- Monitor for side effects of methotrexate.
- Schedule follow-up appointment in three months.

2. Bruising
Assessment: The patient has been experiencing bruising due to the prednisone.
Plan:
- Educate the patient about the risks of prednisone and its impact on bruising.
- Encourage the patient to report any new or worsening bruising.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in three months for follow-up.
- Call the office if any new or worsening symptoms develop.
note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Psoriatic arthritis 
Assessment: The patient has psoriatic arthritis with joint pain and nail changes. Her symptoms have improved with methotrexate. 
Plan: 
- Continue methotrexate. 
- Discontinue prednisone. 
- Order blood work to monitor methotrexate. 

2. Bruising 
Assessment: The patient has easy bruising, likely due to prednisone use. 
Plan: 
- Counsel the patient about the risk of bruising with prednisone. 
- Discontinue prednisone. 

Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 3 months. 
- Call the office if symptoms worsen or if new symptoms develop.

Dialogue:
[doctor] kayla ward , date of birth , 4/28/07 . mrn 3-8-4-9-2-0 . she's here for a new visit with her mother for acne located on the face , which started about two years ago and is present most every day . she has been using persa-gel and washing regularly , which is somewhat helpful . there are no associated symptoms including itching , bleeding , or pain . no additional past medical history . she lives with her parents and sister . they have a dog , bird , and bunnies . she is in 7th grade . she plays basketball and volleyball and tap . she wears sunscreen in the summer , spf 30 . no additional family history . hi kayla , i'm dr. juan price . i hear you are starting to get some acne on the face . how about the chest and back ?
[patient] it's not too bad .
[doctor] so , it's not bad on the chest or back . you've used some over the counter items like washes and persa-gel ?
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] do those seem to be helping ?
[patient] yes , i think so , a little bit .
[doctor] good . what's your skin care routine like now ?
[patient] do you wan na know , like , the things i currently use ?
[doctor] yes . what do you do for your acne in the morning ? and then what do you do at nighttime ?
[patient] i wash my face , more like i wipe it down in the morning . then at night i use an elf facial cleanser called the super clarity cleanser . i finish with a toner and then the persa-gel .
[doctor] when you say , " wipe your face in the morning , " do you use a product or just water ?
[patient] mm , just water and a washcloth , really . if i feel really greasy , sometimes i'll use the elf cleanser in the morning , too .
[doctor] okay . and is today a good day , bad day , or an average day for you ?
[patient] mm , i would say it's probably a good day for me , of course , since i'm here , right ?
[doctor] acne is always good when you come to see the doctor . do you find that your acne flares with your periods ?
[patient] no , not really .
[doctor] and do you get a regular period ?
[patient] yup .
[doctor] how long have you been getting a regular period ?
[patient] mm , i think about two years .
[doctor] okay .
[patient_guest] the biggest flare , probably , was when she started school sports in the fall , just with all the sweating .
[doctor] yup , that will do it . is there anything else that you've noticed , mrs. ward ?
[patient_guest] no . kayla really has been doing a good job with the facial care regimen . it just does n't seem to help as much as we wanted .
[doctor] got it . okay . well , let's take a look then . full exam is performed today , except for under the underwear and under the bra . multiple benign nevi on the trunk and extremities . scattered skin colored papules . open and closed comedones . and erythmateous papules on the face , primarily on the forehead and with also some on the central cheeks and chin . the chest and back are relatively spared . and the remainder of the examination is normal . so , what i'm seeing from your exam today is mild to moderate acne , mostly comodonal with small inflammatory component .
[patient] okay , so is there anything we can do to help it ?
[doctor] yes . i would like to start with a topical therapy first . every morning , you will wash your face with a mild cleanser then use a moisturizer labeled , " noncomedogenic , " with sunscreen spf 30 or higher . this means it wo n't clog your pores . now , in the evening , wash your face with the same cleanser and allow it to dry . apply adapalene , 0.1 % cream , in a thin layer to the areas you generally get acne . i want you to start off using this a few nights a week and slowly work up to using it every night . if it is ... excuse me , if it is very expensive or not covered by insurance , you can try different gel over the counter . you can follow that with clean and clear persa-gel in a thin layer , or where you generally get acne . and then a noncomedogenic moisturizer . you're atopic retinoid will cause some sensitivity , so you will need to wear sunscreen when you are outside . it may also cause some dryness or irritation .
[patient] okay , i can do that .
[doctor] you also have multiple benign moles on your arms , legs , back and abdomen . this means they all look normal with no worrisome features . we will see if you have any progress over the next six months and follow up at that time .
[patient] okay , that sounds good . thank you .
[doctor] do you have any questions for me ?
[patient] no , i do n't think so .
[doctor] okay . if you have questions or concerns before your next visit , please call the office .
[patient] thank you , doctor , we will .
label: sub
note_1:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Acne

History of presenting illness
Ms. Ward is a 16-year-old female with no significant past medical history who presents to the clinic for evaluation of acne on her face.  She states her acne started approximately 2 years ago and has been persistent almost every day. She states it is mainly on her face and " not bad" on her chest or back.  She denies any associated itchiness, pain or bleeding.  No association with her periods. It seems like her biggest flare coincided with increased sweating with her initiation of school sports in the fall. She mentions that today is one of her "good" days. She mentions using persa gel and washing regularly which has helped somewhat. She states she wipes her face down in the morning with water and a wash cloth with super clarity cleanser intermittently. At nighttime, she uses the super clarity cleanser and finishes it with a toner followed by the persa-gel.  She wears sunscreen and summer.
note_2:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Acne.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 15-year-old female who presents to the clinic with a CHIEF COMPLAINT of acne. She reports that she has had acne on her face for approximately 2 years, which is present most every day. The acne is mild to moderate, mostly comodonal with a small inflammatory component. She denies any associated symptoms such as itching, bleeding, or pain. She uses Persa-gel and washes regularly, which is somewhat helpful. She also reports that she gets a regular period and has been getting a regular period for approximately 2 years. Her mother is concerned that the acne may be related to her periods.
note_3:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Acne on the face.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Kayla Ward is a 15-year-old female who presents with a 2-year history of acne on the face. The acne is present most every day and is not too bad on the chest or back. She has been using over-the-counter washes and Persa-Gel, which have been somewhat helpful. She denies any associated symptoms, including itching, bleeding, or pain. She has a regular menstrual cycle and does not find that her acne flares with her periods. The biggest flare was when she started school sports in the fall, likely due to sweating. Her mother reports that Kayla has been doing a good job with her facial care regimen, but it does not seem to help as much as they would like.

label: ap
note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Mild-to-moderate acne
Assessment: Erythematous papules in the face, primarily on the forehead with some on the central cheeks and chin.  Chest and back relatively spared.  Mostly comedonal with small inflammatory component 
Plan: 
-Topical therapy where patient will need to wash face with mild cleanser and then a use a moisturizer labeled non comedogenic with sunscreen SPF 30 or higher.  In the evening, patient will need to wash face with cleanser and allowed to dry.  
-Will consequently apply adapalene, 0.1% cream in a thin layer to areas that generally get acne.  Recommending at least a few nights a week and slowly work up using every night.  
-If expensive were not covered by insurance can try different gel over-the-counter and follow up with clean are clear versus gel and a thin layer on areas with potential acne as well as a non comedogenic moisturizer.  
-The retinoid may cause some sensitivity and so will need to wear sunscreen.

2. Benign nevi
Assessment:
Multiple benign nevi on arms, legs, back and abdomen. No worrisome features.
Plan:
-Follow up over the next 6 months
-Any concerns prior to next visit patient informed to please call office.
note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Acne vulgaris
Assessment: Mild to moderate acne, mostly comedonal with small inflammatory component. Examination reveals open and closed comedones, erythematous papules on the face, primarily on the forehead and with also some on the central cheeks and chin. The chest and back are relatively spared.
Plan:
- Start topical therapy with Adapalene 0.1% cream applied in a thin layer to the affected areas every night.
- Use a noncomedogenic moisturizer after applying Adapalene.
- Apply Clean & Clear Persa-gel in a thin layer or where acne tends to occur.
- Wear sunscreen when outdoors.
- Follow up in 6 months to assess response to treatment.

2. Multiple benign moles on the arms, legs, back, and abdomen
Assessment: No worrisome features. Will monitor for progression over the next 6 months and follow up at that time.
note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Acne vulgaris 
Assessment: The patient has mild to moderate acne, mostly comodonal with small inflammatory component. It started about two years ago and is present most every day. It is worse on the face, primarily on the forehead and with also some on the central cheeks and chin. The chest and back are relatively spared. She has been using over the counter washes and persa-gel, which is somewhat helpful. There are no associated symptoms including itching, bleeding, or pain. 
Plan: 
- Will start topical therapy with adapalene 0.1% cream in the evening and clean and clear persa-gel in a thin layer. 
- Will use a mild cleanser and noncomedogenic moisturizer with sunscreen spf 30 or higher in the morning. 
- Will follow up in 6 months to assess progress. 

2. Multiple benign nevi 
Assessment: The patient has multiple benign nevi on the trunk and extremities. They all look normal with no worrisome features. 
Plan: 
- No treatment is needed at this time. 
- Will follow up in 6 months to reassess. 

Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 6 months for follow up. 
- Call the office if any questions or concerns arise before the next visit.

Dialogue:
[doctor] kelly wood . date of birth , february 15th , 1979 . established patient here for renal ultrasound because of hematuria . urine dipstick today . negative for leukocytes , nitrates , protein , ketone , bilirubin and glucose . color yellow and clear , urobilinogen 0.2 , ph 5.5 and specific gravity 1.020 . there is a trace amount of blood in the urine and intact . renal ultrasound impression . right kidney is 10 cm in length by five centimeter wide . there are no stones , masses or hydronephrosis . the left kidney is 10.8 centimeters in length and five centimeters wide . there is a six millimeter left renal stone non-obstructing . 533 milliliters pre-void and 0 milliliters post-void . hi , mrs. wood . i see you're just finished your ultrasound .
[patient] yes , ma'am .
[doctor] well , it looks like you have one stone in the left kidney but it's not obstructing anything .
[patient] i knew it had to be a kidney stone . i passed what looked like two small stones last week after i scheduled this appointment . and then for the past six weeks , i've had a few episodes of bright red urine the color of , like , cherry kool-aid . and last week , i was constantly having to pee and it hurt something terrible .
[doctor] how bad was your pain on a scale of zero to 10 ? zero being no pain and 10 being worse , as you can imagine .
[patient] um , at the time , i'd say an eight .
[doctor] are you having any flank pain now or tenderness in your lower back ?
[patient] no , after passing those stones , things have felt a lot better .
[doctor] that's good to hear . now , it looks like you're only taking alavert 10 milligrams a day and have no drug allergies . is that correct ?
[patient] that's right .
[doctor] all right , let's take a look at you today . let's use my default pe . well , mrs. wood , we know that the blood in your urine was due to the kidney stones . fortunately , you passed two last week and the blood has nearly subsided . you do still have one stone in the left kidney . since it's not obstructing or causing pain , i do n't recommend any surgical intervention at this time .
[patient] i'd like to know what i can do to stop getting these stones .
[doctor] as we discussed last time , the formation of kidney stones can not be attributed to a particular cause . but several factors increase the risk , such as dehydration , family history , certain foods , digestive tract disease and certain medical conditions .
[patient] yeah , i know i do n't drink near the amount of water that i should . i drink more mountain dew than anything .
[doctor] you should drink about half of your body weight in ounces of water a day .
[patient] so , if i weight 250 pounds , i should drink ?
[doctor] that would be 125 ounces of water a day and you should avoid drinking sugary drinks like mountain dew .
[patient] okay . is there any food i should n't eat ?
[doctor] great question . you should avoid food rich in sodium oxalate and animal protein . so that would be salty , processed food because they're high in sodium . ideally , you should consume less than 1,000 milligrams of sodium a day and reduce the amount of beef , poultry , fish , and pork .
[patient] what's oxalate ?
[doctor] it's an organic acid found in plants , that when digested , it binds to minerals that stones are formed from . foods like spinach , chocolate , beets , rhubarb and soy products .
[patient] well , i'll do whatever it takes to try to avoid getting these stones again .
[doctor] great . and here's a handout that you can look over . it goes over the dietary recommendations and what to avoid .
[patient] okay , good . i like to have things in writing to help me remember .
[doctor] perfect . well , if you have any more questions . if you do n't have any more questions , you're all set . i wo n't need to see you back until next year , as long as you do n't have any more issues like bleeding or pain . if you do have any issues , you can always call the office sooner . and if you experience any severe pain or bright red blood in your urine , you should go to the emergency room .
[patient] all right . well , let's hope we do n't have to do either of those and i see you next year .
[doctor] yes , let's hope . come right this way and i'll walk you to check out . update pe abdomen . no flank pain . anti gu . normal vaginal exam . primary diagnosis is hematuria . secondary diagnosis is chronic urol ... urolithiasis . thank you . this completes mrs. wood encounter .
label: sub
note_1:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Ms. Kelly is a 44-year-old female who presented to clinic after having a renal ultrasound for hematuria.

History of presenting illness
She states that for 6 weeks she has  a few episodes of bright red urine.  She states that last week she constantly had to pee which was associated with significant pain,  8/10 in intensity.  she mentions passing to small stones last week after schedule an appointment with improvement in symptoms.  She denies any current flank pain or tenderness in her lower back.  She mentions that she does not drink as much as she should and instead drinks more mountain dew.
Patient takes alavert 10 mg a day and has no drug allergies.

She also reports that she has been constantly having to pee and it hurts something terrible. The patient denies any flank pain or tenderness in her lower back. She states that she passes two small stones last week and the blood has nearly subsided. She does still have one stone in the left kidney.

He has been playing a lot of tennis recently and has been hitting the cord a lot more, which has been causing pain in his right elbow for the last three weeks. The pain is located on the outside part of his elbow and is an 8/10 when he is using it and a 3/10 when he is resting. It is a sharp, stabbing pain that radiates down his arm. ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Acute lateral epicondylitis of right elbow
Assessment: Patient is now having right elbow pain after starting playing tennis.
Physical exam showed right elbow moderate lateral epicondylar tenderness, moderate pain with passive range of motion, no palpable joint effusion. Right elbow X-ray showed no acute fracture or malalignment.
Plan:
- Apply brace to the right forearm
- Ultram 50mg daily for pain
- Rest the right arm, avoid repetitive stress, stop tennis for 4 to 6 weeks
- Ice the right elbow for 20 minutes at least 3 times per day
- Follow up in 4 weeks in the clinic, re-evaluate at that time and consider additional imaging or physical therapy referral if needed

2. Type 2 diabetes, uncontrolled
Assessment: Blood glucose runs around 150 to 160. He admitted eating quite a lot of sweets recently.
Plan:
- Increase metformin to 1000mg BID
- Recommend checking blood glucose twice daily for the next 2 weeks, and keep a log
- Hemoglobin A1c level, CBC, chem-12 today
- Discussed diet discretions.

3. Mild intermittent asthma
Assessment: well controlled.
Plan:
- Continue Flovent BID and albuterol PRN. Refill albuterol.

- Return to clinic in 4 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen.

His appetite was okay last night, but only had 7 oz milk this morning. He was irritable and could not go to sleep. The patientâ€™s older sister was sick recently and his nephew at the play date also had a sinus infection. His cradle cap was noted to be a little worse despite using cradle cap brush and aveno shampoo.
note_2:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Rash, congestion, and fever.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 6-month-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of rash, congestion, and fever. The mother reports that the child developed a runny nose and nasal congestion yesterday evening. She also notes that the child has been pulling on his ears and rubbing at his nose. He has also been having trouble sleeping due to irritability. The mother denies any recent exposures to illness. She states that she gave the child Tylenol earlier today due to increased sweating. She also mentions that the child has been taking Zarbee's for his cold symptoms.
note_3:
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Review of symptoms.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Randy Gutierrez is a 10-month-old male who presents with a 1-day history of a runny nose, nasal congestion, clear mucous, cough, ear pulling, and irritability. He has a low-grade fever of 100.3 degrees Fahrenheit. His appetite has been variable, and he has been irritable and unable to sleep well. He has been exposed to other sick individuals, including his sister and a nephew with a sinus infection. He has been treated with saline nasal mist, Tylenol, baby Vicks on his feet, and a humidifier. His cradle cap has also worsened.

label: ap
note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Sinusitis
Assessment: The patientâ€™s symptoms including runny nose, fever, cough, and ear pulling suggested a viral sinus infection. The physical exam did not show any ear discharge. He is at risk for bacterial infection but does not require any antibiotics for now. Conservative management is encouraged.
Plan:
-Maintain good fluid intake, encourage resting and monitor for barking cough
-If patient developes a barky cough, can try patientâ€™s sisterâ€™s medication, half a teaspoon for 5 days
-Can use Zarbeeâ€™s for regular cough
-Call clinic if symptom worsened
-Return to clinic in 1 week

2. Cradle cap
Assessment: Patient was noted to have slightly worse cradle cap despite using cradle cap brush and aveno shampoo
Plan:
-Continue to use soft brush and baby oil
-Continue with shampoo twice a week; encouraging regular strength shampoo such as head & shoulderâ€™s, selsun blue or nizoral
-Symptoms shall improve within 6 weeks; if it worsened, call clinic back
note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Viral upper respiratory tract infection (URTI)
Assessment: The patient presents with a runny nose, nasal congestion, and cough. He also has a history of exposure to his older sister who has been sick. Physical exam reveals a clear mucous membrane.
Plan:
- Will monitor closely for signs of progression.
- Recommend supportive care such as hydration, rest, and saline mist in the nose.
- If he develops a barky cough, recommend giving him a half a teaspoon of his sister's medicine.

2. Cradle Cap
Assessment: The patient has cradle cap.
Plan:
- Continue to use the soft brush and some baby oil to remove the scales.
- Use Head & Shoulders, Selsun Blue, or Nizoral Ad once a week.
- Avoid using these products near the eyes.
- Follow up in 6 weeks to assess progress.
note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Viral Upper Respiratory Infection (URI)
Assessment: Runny nose, clear mucous, cough, ear pulling, low-grade fever, irritability, decreased appetite, exposure to sick individuals. Physical exam: No significant findings.
Plan:
- Continue supportive care: fluids, rest.
- Monitor for worsening symptoms, especially a barky cough.
- If barky cough develops, administer half a teaspoon of sister's cough medicine (as needed).
- Consider Zarbee's cough syrup for regular cough (dose for under 1 year of age).
- Follow up in 1 week.

2. Cradle Cap
Assessment: Worsening cradle cap.
Plan:
- Use dandruff shampoo (Head & Shoulders, Selsun Blue, Nizoral AD) twice per week.
- Continue using cradle cap brush and baby oil to remove scales.
- Avoid getting shampoo in eyes.
- Follow up if condition worsens.

Wayne presents to clinic for a foot sore that has not healed well.

History of presenting illness

He initially noticed a blister which has since worsened. He denies any fevers or chills.  He saw his PCP prior to presentation and was prescribed antibiotics and referred here to podiatry. Right foot wound.

The patient reports having a wound on his right foot for approximately 2 to 3 weeks. He denies any history of trauma to the foot. He states that he has been using a band-aid on the wound, and he completed a course of antibiotics yesterday. He denies any pain associated with the wound. He also denies any fevers, chills, drainage from the wound, or any other symptoms. He states that he is still wearing the same shoes that caused the problem. Non-healing sore on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant male who presents with a 2-3 week history of a non-healing sore on the dorsal aspect of the lateral right foot. He denies any trauma to the foot. He initially noticed a blister after wearing new shoes, but the blister has since worsened. He has been applying a band-aid to the wound, but it continues to stick to the wound when he removes his sock. He denies any pain, fever, chills, or drainage from the wound.

The patient has a history of neuropathy and has had issues with stability in the past. He has been wearing a surgical shoe to take pressure off the area.

His last HbA1c was slightly over 8%.

label: ap
note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Diabetic foot ulcer
Assessment: Patient presents with a wound that has been present for approximately 2-3 weeks.  Denies any pain to the area. Vital signs unremarkable. A1c a little over 8. A 1 x 2 in circular wound  appreciated on the dorsal aspect of the right lateral foot just proximal to the right fifth  MTP joint with some yellow slough present and minimal granulation tissue.  No surrounding erythema or cellulitis and no evidence of fluid collection.  No odor or necrosis.  No bony exposure.  Bilateral femoral and popliteal pulses palpable.  No palpable DP or PT pulses; however, Doppler signs are present.  Nontender to palpation.
X-ray performed just prior to presentation shows no evidence of osteomyelitis. Patient has a diabetic foot ulcer with no signs or evidence of osteomyelitis.   Was recently treated with antibiotics; however at this time no signs of infection. Likely exacerbated by tight fitting shoes and elevated A1c.
Plan: 
-Ankle-brachial index to determine blood supply to foot
-Debridement in office to take off some of the dead tissue 
-Collagenase ointment to be applied to wound once daily and then cover with a dry sterile dressing. Patient to continue this until wound starts to shrink and pink tissue present
-Surgical shoe to take pressure off the area
-No antibiotics at this time as they are likely not needed 
-Diabetic consult to improve hemoglobin A1c
-Return to clinic in 2 weeks. Will follow up ABI results at that time.  If ABI indicating blood supply not optimal, possible referral to a vascular specialist.
note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Diabetic foot ulcer 
Assessment: The patient has a diabetic foot ulcer that is not healing, with no evidence of osteomyelitis on X-ray. He has a history of poorly controlled diabetes with HbA1C of 8.2%. 
Plan: 
- Order ABIs to evaluate blood flow to the foot. 
- Perform debridement in the office. 
- Prescribe collagenase ointment to be applied once daily. 
- Refer to vascular specialist if necessary. 
- Continue to monitor wound healing and adjust treatment as needed. 
- Consider diabetic consult to help manage diabetes and improve wound healing. 

2. Poorly controlled diabetes 
Assessment: The patient has a history of poorly controlled diabetes with HbA1C of 8.2%. 
Plan: 
- Consult with diabetes specialist to discuss management options. 

3. Neuropathy 
Assessment: The patient has a history of neuropathy. 
Plan: 
- Monitor closely and consider further evaluation and treatment as needed.
note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Diabetic Foot Ulcer
Assessment: Non-healing ulcer on the dorsal aspect of the lateral right foot, proximal to the fifth metatarsophalangeal joint. Yellow slough present with minimal granulation tissue. No surrounding erythema, cellulitis, fluid collection, necrosis, or odor. No bony exposure.Palpable bilateral femoral and popliteal pulses; doppler signs present in dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial arteries.
- X-ray shows no evidence of osteomyelitis.
Plan:
- Order ankle brachial index (ABI) to assess blood supply to the foot.
- Perform in-office debridement to remove dead tissue.
- Prescribe collagenase ointment to be applied once daily and covered with a dry sterile dressing.
- Wear a surgical shoe to take pressure off the area.
- Consider referral to a vascular specialist if ABI indicates suboptimal blood supply for wound healing.

2. Diabetes
Assessment: Hemoglobin A1c slightly elevated at 8%.
Plan: Encourage patient to improve diabetes control to promote wound healing. Consider diabetic consult for dietary modifications and other measures to lower hemoglobin A1c.

Follow-up Instructions:
- Return to clinic in two weeks for wound re-evaluation.

[patient] yes . that's right .
[doctor] okay . perfect . let me just get logged in , here . have you met with anyone before about a breast reduction ?
[patient] no , i have n't .
[doctor] okay . and how long have you been considering this ?
[patient] it's probably been about six or seven years . but i mean , it's always been in the back of my mind .
[doctor] well , i perform a lot of breast reduction surgeries , pretty much every week , so it is a very common procedure .
[patient] okay , that's reassuring .
[doctor] yeah . so what i wan na do first is just get a little bit of history about the sort of symptoms that you're having . and then i'll do a quick exam .
[patient] okay . that sounds good .
[doctor] and then we'll talk more about the surgery and what it entails . and , um , at this point , who is your insurance provider ?
[patient] i have blue cross blue shield . well , actually , my husband just accepted a new job , and i will be on his plan , uh , which i believe is not going to be blue cross , but it may be changing .
[doctor] okay . what we typically do when we do a breast reduction consult , i'll document your symptoms , symptoms , we'll take some pictures , then , um , they get sent to the insurance company . and what they'll do is decide whether it's approved , or medically necessary , or not . but we wan na make sure we send it to the right insurance . do you know when you'll be on the new plan ?
[patient] most likely july .
[doctor] okay . so we may just wait until july to submit for approval at that time .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so regarding your symptoms , do you experience back pain ?
[patient] well , i've been going to the chiropractor for a few years . i do have a lotta pain here and here . but i do n't know if it's all from my breasts or not . it gets painful and builds up . so i think i could attribute it to my breasts , when i'm working at my desk all day .
[doctor] okay . and in your neck and your upper back . and how long has this been going on ? would you say five years , 10 years , or even since puberty ?
[patient] i would say since i was in high school .

[doctor] yeah , i have heard that as well . and , um , have you had any children , or are you planning to have any children in the future ?
[patient] no , i do not have any kids now . but we might plan to in the future .
[doctor] okay . and at this time , are you experiencing any numbness or tingling in the s- in the hands or any nipple pain ?
[patient] sometimes , yes .
[doctor] okay . and rashes , do you get any rashes underneath your breasts ? and , and it could be from sweating .
[patient] no , but they are always sweaty .
[doctor] okay . and then do you feel like your activities are limited because of the size ?
[patient] there's certain things i do when i have to hold them , like working out and any jumping or running . and it hurts .
[doctor] and it hurts , okay . and , and you saw a chiropractor . but what about physical therapy for your back pain ? or do you take any pain medicine for it ?
[patient] y- no , but i do take a migraine medication , propranolol .
[doctor] that's okay . so let's see . i know that you have a history of breast cancer in your family . have you had any mammograms ? and how old was your mother when she had it ?
[patient] mom was 40 . and they recommended me starting at age 30 for mammogram . i'm still ... i mean , i'm 25 . so i'm still a little bit young .
[doctor] okay . and otherwise , it seems like you're really healthy ?
[patient] yes , for the most part . i lost about 10 pounds over the past few months , and i still would like to lose about 20 more pounds .
[doctor] congratulations . that's great . and then , um-
[patient] thank you .
[doctor] . so then ... you're welcome . and so do you use any tobacco , drugs , or alcohol ? and then , um , you said that you were going to school . what are you going to school for ?
[patient] uh , i drink a little wine on occasion , and for school , i'm currently studying psychology .
[doctor] okay , that's great . all right . so what we'll do is we'll go ahead and take a look . i'm gon na take a couple of measurements . and we'll kinda talk about the surgery afterwards . um , so go ahead and stand up for me , julia . okay . so , looking at the measurements , it looks like one breast is a little lower than the other .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] okay . well , thank you so much . it looks like i have all the measurements that we need . you can go ahead and cover up now .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so i think you're a great candidate for a breast reduction . when we talk about a breast reduction , what happens is that we remove the tissue out of the breast .
[patient] okay . that's fine .
[doctor] and we would then lift them and elevate the nipple position in order to help with your back pain , neck pain , and because i'm a plastic surgeon , of course i want them to look nice as well .
[patient] right .
[doctor] so typically , when you do the breast reduction , we make an incision around the nipple straight down and then underneath . and it kinda looks like , um , an anchor below . then straight down , and underneath , and through that incision , we're able to f- to lift the breast . and we'll take off any extra fat and breash- breast tissue . so that way it becomes smaller in size . and i noticed that you would like to be a b cup . so i do tell every patient we can make you as small as your blood supply allows . and what that means is we must move the nipple without cutting off any of its blood supply during the surgery .
[patient] okay . well , thank you for explaining that .
[doctor] you're welcome . and in your case , you'll probably be a small c. um , a b cup might be a little bit small , but we'll see once i'm doing the , the procedure for you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and typically the surgery takes about three hours . you will have drains , one in each side . and that helps prevent fluid from building up in the breast . and that stays in for about a week . and then we'll remove them in the clinic . and you'll have a clear plastic tape over your incision that should help with the scars . and , um , we've seen that patients who have lighter skin , the scars will tend to be red at first . and then it takes about a year for a scar to mature in line .
[patient] okay . well , i'm not too worried about the scars .
[doctor] okay . and i do like to keep patients overnight . it's just going to be for one night in the hospital . and we just wan na make sure your pain is controlled , make sure you're not nauseated , all of that stuff . some patients wan na go home that same day . but you know that some people get nauseated , and the last thing that i want is for you to be vomiting at home alone without the , the support here at the facility .
[patient] okay , yeah , that sounds good .
[doctor] okay . and then about 30 % of patients say that they can not breastfeed after a breast reduction , and the reason is the breast is made up of fat . and it's also made up of a gland . and the gland is what produces the milk .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and so in order to reduce the size of the breast , we have to take out both the fat and the glands . so it just depends on how much is left , whether you can breastfeed in the future . and then also , the breast will change over time . if you , um , gain weight , they will get larger , things like that .
[patient] yeah , okay .
[doctor] and if you have children , they will change as well . they will enlarge , especially if you can breastfeed . but they'll go back down and will appear , um , a little bit deflated .
[patient] yeah . i do n't know if i'm interested in breastfeeding .
[doctor] okay . um , the hormones of pregnancy , though , will change the breasts , so that's just something to be aware of , and i tell all younger patients that .
[patient] okay , yeah . absolutely .
[doctor] and then typically nipple sensation is fine after a breast reduction , but there is a slight chance that you'll have an alteration in the nipple sensation or not have any sensation in the nipple . generally the nipple is just fine unless it is a massive reduction . and it's quite normal after surgery to be a little bit bruised , and then it just takes some time for that to go away .
[patient] yeah , okay .
[doctor] but other than that , you know , most patients are very happy after the breast reduction because the symptoms of the back pain , the neck pain , you can feel relief almost immediately . so do you have any questions , julia , about the process or anything like that ?
[patient] no , not really .
[doctor] okay . and , i do think you're a good candidate for it . and i think you'll benefit from it as well .
[patient] good . i look forward to a relief .
[doctor] i think you just have to do it when you are ready , when you know that you feel like it's a good time , because it is a commitment , and you will have some activity restrictions for about six weeks after surgery , uh , no heavy lifting . and i do say no driving for two to three weeks . and the drains stay in , like i said , for about a week .
[patient] okay . well , i am ready as soon as my insurance is switched over .
[doctor] okay . well , i think from this point , if you want to , we can take photos today , while you're here . i have all the documentation now in the note about your symptoms , and that's what the insurance company is going to look for . so thank you for answering those questions . so once we have the new provider , we'll go ahead and get that submitted . and then , when they approve it , um , what the office will do , is they'll work with you on a surgery date , and then we'll meet again right before the surgery to answer any last minute questions and go over the instructions in more detail , things like that .
[patient] okay . well , i will notify the office as soon as i have the insurance information .
[doctor] that sounds great . and then we can get it all in process . and it was so nice to meet you . and catherine will be right in to get your photos . julia jones is a 25 year old female with symptomatic macromastia , presenting for evaluation of breast reduction . the patient has attempted nonsurgical treatments , but the minimal relief , and is an ideal candidate for bilateral reduction mammoplasty . her minimum required resection , based on a bsa of 2.65 , with the schnur scale is 1,792 grams , which should be attainable . given her extremely large breasts and the measurements above , there is potential for using a nipple graft .
